entry.title: Accelerating Testing with SAP Cloud ALM and Tricentis TTA: Codeless Automation for RISE Transitions
entry.content:
In today's fast-paced agile environments, regression testing often becomes the bottleneck that slows down delivery cycles.

Teams face a challenging paradox: the need for comprehensive test coverage versus the pressure to release quickly.

Tricentis Test Automation for SAP integrated with SAP Cloud ALM offers a pragmatic solution that bridges this gap—one we've validated across multiple customer implementations in Latin America.

A Fool with a Tool Is Still a Fool

Before diving into the technology, let's address the elephant in the room.

The testing industry is littered with failed automation initiatives where organizations invested heavily in sophisticated tools only to see minimal return.

Why? Because they treated automation as a silver bullet rather than what it truly is: an enabler that amplifies your existing capabilities.

The best tool in the world won't compensate for poorly defined test strategies, unclear requirements, or teams that lack fundamental testing skills.

Tricentis TTA is powerful, but its success depends entirely on the people wielding it and the processes supporting them.

Codeless doesn't mean thoughtless.

The Agile Testing Challenge

Traditional regression testing approaches were designed for waterfall methodologies—lengthy test cycles executed at the end of development phases.

Agile demands something different: continuous validation that keeps pace with sprint cadences.

The question becomes not whether to automate, but how to automate intelligently within the constraints of time, budget, and team capacity.

Why Tricentis TTA for SAP Cloud ALM?

What makes this solution particularly attractive for agile teams is its core design philosophy: codeless, easy to use, and fast.

Being fully SaaS and hosted by SAP eliminates infrastructure overhead, allowing teams to focus on what matters—building quality into their releases.

The integration supports both SAP web and desktop applications, covering the majority of regression scenarios organizations face during S/4HANA implementations and ongoing operations.

For teams ready to begin, Tricentis provides clear guidance at https://docs.tricentis.com/sap-tta-calm-cloud/en-us/content/get_started.htm, with dedicated paths for administrators setting up the environment and testers building their first automated test suites.

Real-World Impact: Latin America RISE Transitions

Over the past months, we have successfully applied this solution across several customers in Latin America, and the results speak for themselves. Organizations undergoing RISE with SAP transitions, S/4HANA upgrades, and system conversions face an enormous regression testing burden—every customization, every integration, every business process needs validation.

Tricentis TTA integrated with SAP Cloud ALM has proven invaluable in these scenarios. The codeless approach allowed our customers' functional teams to participate directly in test automation, dramatically reducing the time needed to build comprehensive regression suites. What previously took weeks of manual testing effort could be automated and executed in hours, giving project teams the confidence to proceed with their transformations without compromising quality.

The SaaS delivery model was particularly beneficial for our Latin American customers, eliminating the need for complex on-premise infrastructure and enabling rapid deployment even in organizations with limited IT resources dedicated to testing.

Tools Succeed When People and Processes Align

In every successful implementation we've delivered, the common factor wasn't the tool itself—it was the combination of skilled testers who understood both the business and testing fundamentals, clear automation strategies defining what to automate and why, proper governance ensuring test assets remain maintainable, and executive sponsorship treating quality as a priority rather than an afterthought.

Tricentis TTA lowers the technical barrier to automation, but it doesn't eliminate the need for testing expertise. Use it wisely: automate the right things, maintain your test assets, and continuously evaluate whether your automation is delivering value.

Scaling Beyond SAP

For organizations looking to extend automation beyond SAP applications to their entire business landscape, the natural evolution path leads to SAP Enterprise Continuous Testing by Tricentis—providing a unified approach to quality across heterogeneous environments.

Practical Recommendations

Start with your most critical regression scenarios. Identify the business processes that run every sprint, carry the highest risk, and currently consume the most manual testing effort.

The codeless approach means your functional experts—those who understand the business—can contribute directly to automation without waiting for scripting resources.

For organizations planning RISE with SAP transitions or major upgrades, investing in TTA early in the project pays dividends throughout the journey—from initial testing through go-live and into steady-state operations.

But invest equally in your people. Train them, develop their skills, and ensure they understand not just how to use the tool, but when and why.

The path to agile quality assurance isn't about having the most sophisticated tools—it's about using the right tools effectively, with the right skills, within the right context.

SAP Cloud ALM

entry.title: Re: From On-Premise to Cloud: Making the Right SAP ERP Move
entry.content:
Hi Patrick,

Thanks for the feedback!

The Managed Service Provider (MSP) model is not described in this article because it is a unique delivery model that warrants a separate article. MSP is a partner company that contracts directly with SAP to purchase and resell SAP cloud solutions (such as SAP Cloud ERP Private) to its own end-customers - usually bundled with the MSP's own offerings.

The MSP manages the customer relationship independently. SAP’s contractual, operational, and support obligations exist only with the MSP, not with the MSP’s end-customers. 

The model comes with it's own guardrails and currently support SAP Cloud ERP Private, tailored option, but not all deployment- and delivery models as described in this article. Therefore, this should be assessed on a case-by-case basis through the SAP Technical Assessment process.

Hope that helps.

KR, Nikolaj

entry.title: Re: Why does SAP always use Periodic Unit Price for valua...
entry.content:
In SAP, when Price Control = V (Moving Average Price), valuation is always based on the Periodic Unit Price (PUP). The Standard Price is ignored by design in valuation postings under this setting. This is a hard‑coded SAP design decision, not influenced by configuration. The Standard Price field remains in the material master for informational, reporting, and planning purposes only, but it cannot be used as the valuation base when Price Control = V.

Why SAP ignores Standard Price under Price Control V is because of the following:

Moving Average Price logic: With Price Control V, SAP recalculates the material price after every goods receipt, invoice receipt, or order settlement. The valuation basis is always the average of total stock value ÷ total stock quantity. Check this SAP Help Price Control with and Without Actual Costing 

Standard Price logic: With Price Control S, valuation is fixed at the maintained standard price, and variances are posted to price difference accounts.

Design principle: SAP enforces a strict separation between the two methods to avoid mixing fixed and dynamic valuation bases. This separation is intentional and embedded in the valuation program logic.

SAP Note 81682 explicitly recommends using Price Control S for semi‑finished and finished products, while Price Control V is intended for raw materials. This confirms SAP’s design intent and limitation of V

entry.title: From “What Broke?” to “Why It Happened” : Industrial Systems in SAP Asset Performance Management
entry.content:
Managing Industrial Systems

Introduction

If you’ve been working with SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), you already know it’s built to help organisations manage their assets more intelligently — not just individually, but as part of a connected technical system. 

In the latest evolution of Asset Performance Management, the Industrial System functionality has been enhanced to represent complex system hierarchies better — think of trains, turbines, or production lines with hundreds of interconnected parts. 
In this blog, we’ll explore what an Industrial System actually is, how it’s modelled in APM, and why the ISO 81346 standard plays such an important role in making it all work seamlessly. 

Why do we need Industrial Systems? 

The current asset structuring approach offers only a single perspective. Customers are required to choose one primary structure to represent their assets, which limits flexibility. As a result, end users struggle to locate and manage assets from different viewpoints or functional contexts.

Industrial systems run on systems, not isolated assets. A train isn’t just an engine, a turbine isn’t just a rotor. 
This complexity creates real challenges for customers! 

  • Hard-to-see dependencies: When one component fails, it affects the behaviour of many others. Without system-level visibility, root-cause analysis becomes guesswork. 
  • Growing scale and variability: Modern fleets and production lines evolve constantly, with new configurations, new technologies, and new maintenance strategies that need consistent modelling.

With industrial systems in SAP Asset Performance Management, we solve these challenges by providing a unified, structured and standardized way to display how assets actually work together. Instead of managing “collections of equipment”, we can manage a “functioning system” with consistency and clarity. 

What is an Industrial System?

An Industrial System is a group of interrelated components that work together as a single unit within a specific context. Each of those components — called System Elements — can also be systems on their own. 
Imagine a train as an industrial system. 
It includes elements like: 

  • The railcar 
  • The engine 
  • The brake system
  • The air conditioning unit 

Each of these can be broken down further, forming a hierarchy of connected systems. 
In Asset Performance Management(APM), the Industrial System acts as a master data object, complementing the technical object structure maintained in SAP ERP. This means you get a more modular, system-oriented view of your assets — perfect for analyzing performance and managing complexity across large installations. 
Here are some examples of industrial systems: 

  • Train - The train system consists of various system elements, such as railcar, engine, brake system, air conditioning system. Some of the different system elements are themselves systems that can be created as an industrial system with their different aspects in the Manage Industrial Systems application.
  • Production plant - A production plant is divided into different production departments or production areas. In each production department or area, there are assets that are made up of machines, sensors, and so on. You can create a production plant as an industrial system and define a structure with the various aspects down to the lowest level of the asset. 

Train Industrial System Example

ISO 81346 and Its Role in SAP Asset Performance Management

To bring structure to all of this, APM follows the ISO 81346 standard — an international guideline for organizing and naming complex technical systems. 

The standard defines three key ways to look at any industrial system: 

  • Function: What it does
  • Product: What it is
  • Location: Where it is 

Asset Performance Management(APM) uses a Reference Designator Library aligned with ISO 81346 to assign structured identifiers (or “reference designations”) to each node and element. 
This not only keeps everything standardized and easy to understand, but also ensures that different teams — from engineering to maintenance — speak the same “language” when referring to system components. 

Industrial System Aspects Hierarchy

Streamlining with Industrial System Templates 

Industrial System Templates are all about reusability and consistency. By defining a common structure once, you can: 

  • Standardize modelling practices across teams 
  • Speed up new industrial system creation
  • Reduce errors and manual effort

This makes templates a great starting point for organizations managing multiple similar industrial systems. 

Reference Designation System (RDS): Speaking a Common Language 

The Reference Designation System(RDS) gives an unambiguous way of identifying the purpose or task of an object i.e Aspect Element in the System (ISO 81346-2).  
The reference designation identifies objects for the creation and retrieval of information about an object and, where realized, about its corresponding component. 
A reference designation labelled at a component is the key to finding information about that object among different kinds of documents. 
For example: 
=F1+A12-M3 
can be read as: 

  • =F1 → Functional System 1 
  • +A12 → Located in area A12
  • -M3 → Motor 3 in that area 

RDS eliminates confusion and ensures that everyone — from engineers to maintenance planners — knows exactly which component is being discussed. 

Reference Designation System Structure

Introduction to Reference Designator Libraries

Configuration Manager: Setting the Stage 

The Enable System Configuration toggle in the Configuration Manager - Industrial Systems application is disabled by default and users do not have access to configurations, tiles, system elements and the extensions related to the industrial system feature. 

  • Once you have activated the toggle, users can access these functions.
  • To access the configuration options of the industrial system, you must set the Enable System Configuration toggle to Yes. 

Once you have set the Enable System Configuration toggle to Yes, deactivation is no longer allowed. To still be able to deactivate the toggle, you must ensure that no instances of type Industrial System or Naming Authority are created. 

Pre-shipped configurations, which are the configuration data to create the reference designator libraries and industrial systems:

Industry Domain:
Industry domains are a mandatory part of reference designator libraries, which are structured according to ISO 81346. 
The pre-shipped industry domains are: 

  • RAIL (Railway Industry) 
  • UTIL (Utilities) 
  • OG (Oil & Gas Industry)
  • MISC (Miscellaneous)

Naming Authority:
The names of standard naming authorities that are pre-shipped provide the standards for the coding principles for creating reference designators. 
The pre-shipped naming authorities are: 

  • ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 
  • ANSI (American National Standards Institute) 
  • NEMA (National Electrical Manufacturers Association) 
  • AFNOR (French Association for Standardization) 
  • IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) 
  • JIS (Japanese Industrial Standards) 
  • DIN (German Institute for Standardization) 
  • BSI (Bureau of Indian Standards) 
  • API (American Petroleum Institute) 
  • NORSOK (Norwegian Standards Organization) 
  • MISC (Miscellaneous)
  • IEC (International Electrotechnical Commission) 

Aspects:
A specified way of viewing an industrial system is called as an aspect. Aspects act like filters for a specific perspective of an industrial system. 
The pre-shipped naming authorities are: 

  • FAO 
  • PAO
  • LAO 

Relationship Types:
A relationship type is defined as the type of relationships between System Elements. 
The pre-shipped relationship types are: 

  • CHILD_OF_BLOCK: Block is child of block 
  • PARENT_OF_BLOCK: Block is parent of block 
  • LOCATION: Location block is location of product block 
  • LOCATED: Product block is located at location block 
  • REALIZES: Product block realizes function block 
  • REALIZED: Function block realized by product block 
  • INSTANTIATES_PRODUCT: Product individual instantiates product block
  • PRODUCT_INSTANTIATED_BY: Product block instantiated by product individual 

The above configuration feeds into the Reference Designator Library and Industrial System apps, ensuring everything runs consistently and accurately. 

Standard Role Collections for building Industrial Systems

Configuration Manager:

  • IndustrialSystemConfiguration_Create 
  • IndustrialSystemConfiguration_Read 
  • IndustrialSystemConfiguration_Update
  • IndustrialSystemConfiguration_Delete 

Reference Designator Library:

  • ReferenceDesignatorSchema_Create 
  • ReferenceDesignatorSchema_Read 
  • ReferenceDesignatorSchema_Update
  • ReferenceDesignatorSchema_Delete 

 Industrial System:

  • IndustrialSystem_Create 
  • IndustrialSystem_Update 
  • IndustrialSystem_Read
  • IndustrialSystem_Delete 

Industrial System Template: 

  • TemplateSystem_Read
  • TemplateSystem_Edit 

Building and Managing Industrial Systems — Step by Step 

The Manage Industrial Systems app in APM makes it easy to create, modify, and visualize complex system structures. Here’s a quick walkthrough of how it works: 

It’s visual, intuitive, and flexible — exactly what complex asset structures need. 

  1. Open the App: 
    Go to Asset Management → Asset Data and Information Management → Manage Industrial Systems.
    The application will give an overview and details about the industrial system.
    SAP Asset Performance Management: Manage Industrial System

  2. Browse or Filter Existing Industrial Systems: 
    Use built-in filters, sorting, and grouping options to manage your systems easily.
    Filter the Industrial System List View

  3. Create a New Industrial System:
    Industrial System New Option
    3.1 Choose Create → New and provide details like System ID, description, and perspective. The perspective helps define the system's boundaries. 
    An Industrial System can be added manually or using a coding mask. A Coding Mask helps establish a unique naming convention for Object IDs, such as industrial systems and industrial system elements. 
    The configuration manager application allows you to: 
    Add or edit a coding mask. 
    Activate or deactivate a coding mask. 
    Create Industrial System

    3.2 Reuse Template
    Use Create → From Template to build systems faster using reusable templates. 

    Create Industrial System from Template

    3.3 Import from Excel:
    Prefer bulk uploads? Use Create → From Excel to import data from a pre-formatted spreadsheet. 

    Create Industrial System from Excel

  4. View and Edit Details: 
    This provides the basic details of the industrial system and who created it.

    View the details of created industrial system

  5. Add multilingual translations:
    Use the Translation feature to maintain multilingual descriptions and long text. When these language-specific descriptions and long texts are stored in the respective sections, users will automatically see the system descriptions and long text in their logged-in language, provided translations are available.
    Support of translations in the object page

  6. Edit the hierarchy: 
    Industrial System supports the CAP (Cloud Application Programming) Draft feature.
    Use Edit to build a hierarchy with top nodes, system elements, and product individuals. 

    Edit the details of industrial system

  7. Add Top Nodes: 
    Use the ‘+’ icon to add top nodes. 
    Top Nodes allow us to build the aspect-based hierarchy.

    Create the new top node

  8. Add System Elements: 
    Use the ‘+’ icon on the top node to add system elements.
    The system elements are associated with the selected top node.

    Create the new system element
    Create the new system element

  9. Excel support to update or build hierarchy:  
    Import/Export detailed system hierarchy using Excel with multiple sheets. 
    The already-created system can also be modified using Excel in the object page.

    Excel support to update or build hierarchy
    Excel support to update or build hierarchy
    Excel support to update or build hierarchy

  10. Details of top nodes and system elements: 
    Use info icons to view details of nodes and system elements.

    Details of top node
    Details of top node
    Details of system element

  11. Manage Relationships: 
    Create or remove connections between elements to show how different aspects relate.
    The relationship types are fetched from the configuration manager.

    Managing relationships between system elements

  12. Additional Attributes support (Function aspect only): 
    The attributes “Failure Data Profile” and Functional Failure” can be defined.

    Defining attributes

  13. Assign Technical Objects: 
    Link equipment or functional locations to the product aspects for end-to-end traceability. 
     

    Assigning Technical Objects

     

  14. Visualise the Hierarchy: 
    Toggle between Graph and Table views for a clear picture of your system’s structure.

    Graphical represenatation of industrial system hierarchy
    Tabular represenatation of industrial system hierarchy

It’s visual, intuitive, and flexible — exactly what complex asset structures need. 

Introduction to Industrial Systems

APIs and Integration

For developers, SAP provides public APIs to handle CRUD operations for Industrial Systems, Top Nodes, System Elements, and Relationships. 
Explore for more information - Industrial System APIs - SAP Business Accelerator Hub

Excel Import with Job Manager

Creating large systems manually can be tedious — so SAP has made it easier. 
You can now import an Industrial System directly from an Excel file (.xlsx or .xls). A downloadable template is available within the app; fill in your details and upload it.  Behind the scenes, the Job Manager handles the process asynchronously, ensuring that large imports are smooth and efficient. 

Industrial System Vision

The goal of Industrial Systems is to help the world’s assets operate more efficiently.

APM supports asset-intensive industries by improving the way maintenance and inspection activities are prepared and optimised for large numbers of technical objects. This approach tackles one of the most significant challenges in these industries: managing complexity at scale.

Summary

The Industrial System feature in SAP Asset Performance Management provides a structured and standardized way to manage complex assets.
With support for the ISO 81346 standard, CAP-based development, and easy-to-use Fiori applications, APM enables teams to:

  • Model systems more efficiently
  • Gain better visibility and alignment across teams
  • Simplify maintenance and scale operations

Whether you manage a fleet, a power plant, or a production line, Industrial Systems in APM offer the flexibility and control needed to handle complexity effectively.
Start exploring Industrial Systems in SAP Asset Performance Management to build smarter and more maintainable asset structures.

A Day in the Life of a Reliability Engineer

entry.title: Re: Enable Posting of Supplier Invoices with Zero Amount
entry.content:
Hello @Andrea_Gr 

Thank you for your question.

Thank you for the clarification. There are a few points that needs to be highlighted based on your details.

First, the public cloud does not allow you to post a supplier invoice with 0.00 Gross Amount. The system has a hard-coded validation that says vendor gross amount must be positive. So, the business case you described where you want to offset debit and credit lines with VAT but vendor balance = 0 cannot be modelled as a single supplier invoice document. This is to ensure auditability.

What I recommend in that case is to model the situation as one normal invoices plus one supplier credit memo where you use the same tax code and base amount.

Post the invoice and ensure your G/L lines for expense with tax code V1 (22%) etc.

Then post the credit memo, reference the same vendor document number in the Reference field or auditability. Make sure you use same tax code and same base amount but opposite sign on the clearing account.

Using the Manage Supplier Line Items or through the automatic payment run, both items will net to 0.00 for the vendor. This will reflect in the VAT registers.

Here is a reference for more details.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/01060a2e758f4e8a9d4a7cf07b0ce323.html?locale=en-US https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/2bedd663002149e1b8c03b8667845719.html?locale=en-US

Second, if there is no external supplier invoice and you only need an internal clearing with VAT, I suggest you use FI journal entry for pure internal netting instead of supplier invoice.

Make sure you post your Debit and Credit G/L accounts with tax code V1 so that VAT is calculated on both sides according to your local rules. Your vendor line items can be added only as needed to represent the liability. The overall balance will be zero but your tax postings will still appear correctly.

Here is a reference for more details.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/950f8054747b053de10000000a441470.html?locale=en-US

Summary:

  • The M8 140 blockage is a standard check to ensure Gross Amount is positive and the public cloud does not offer any configuration or BAdI for you to turn it into a warning or to bypass it.
  • Use a normal invoice plus a supplier credit memo to achieve your goal. You may consider using Post General Journal Entries to model the offsetting lines with the appropriate tax codes.
  • The public cloud blocks Zero-gross supplier invoices to keep vendor open items, tax amounts and audit trail consistent.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Modeling Convention in Signavio Process Manager
entry.content:
Hi there,

Thank you for your question!

At the moment, SAP Signavio Process Manager does not support configuring conditional-mandatory logic when the controlling field is a main attribute (such as Task Type). This means that setting the “Task System” field as mandatory only when the task type is Automatic or User, while leaving it optional for Manual tasks, is not currently possible through the standard modeling checks.

If this capability would be valuable for your use case, we strongly encourage you to submit it as an enhancement request on our Influence Page. Our product team actively monitors these requests to understand demand and prioritize future improvements.

We appreciate your feedback, as it helps us continuously improve the product.
Please feel free to share any additional context or questions!

entry.title: Re: Warehouse Management - Clear Negative Stock from 902 Stype
entry.content:
The -20 on your 902 line indicates that there is still a quantity to be processed.

I’m not familiar with the configuration of your internal WM system, but generally, when you reverse a 101 movement, the system generates a 102 movement, as you mentioned. This also creates a transfer request, which is then followed by a transfer order. This step can be either automatic or manual, depending on your system setup.
When you confirm the transfer order, a quantity of 20 will be posted to your 902 line. In your case, the 20 entered against the -20 would bring the line to zero. To do this, there must be a positive quantity of 20 of that material somewhere in your bin location.

However, in your screenshot, I only see the -20 on the 902 line. Where is the corresponding 20 from the second inbound delivery?

entry.title: Re: MRP Not Converting Demand from Old to New Materials i...
entry.content:
Yes — MRP discontinuation logic in SAP is sensitive to phantom BOM structures and the way effectivity dates and follow‑up groups are defined. If both old and new components are present simultaneously in the BOM (duplicate line items with overlapping validity), MRP will still plan requirements for the discontinued items instead of transferring them to the follow‑up materials. The Standard SAP design requires clear validity intervals (old item valid‑to date, new item valid‑from date) and consistent discontinuation indicators in either the material master or BOM. If these are not aligned, MRP generates negative requirements on the old components.

What you should check is

Validity intervals: Ensure that A, B, C have valid‑to dates ending 10/27/2025 and X, Y, Z have valid‑from dates starting 10/28/2025. No overlap should exist.

Discontinuation groups: Verify that the discontinuation group (DisGp 01 → FolGp 01) is consistently assigned to both old and new items in the BOM.

Material master vs BOM: If you maintain follow‑up material in the material master (MRP4 view) and in the BOM, the BOM definition takes precedence. Make sure they are aligned.

MRP run type: Test with a full regenerative MRP run (MD01) instead of a net change run (MD02), as discontinuation logic sometimes only triggers in full runs.

Phantom BOM flag: Confirm that the phantom item category is correctly set (item category “N”), otherwise MRP may treat it differently.

entry.title: Re: Onboarding Reminder Emails Settings - reminders trigger
entry.content:
Dear @kasebc 

For your scenarios:

  1. The countdown is reversed for the "before" scenario, sending reminders every three days leading up to the due date.
  2. If the number of reminders is unspecified, it defaults to "0," it allows as many reminders as possible until the due date.
  3. This functionality applies to both "before" and "after" scenarios, meaning that after the due date is reached, the reminder is sent the many times it is configured.

Scenario: Reminder email gets triggered 4th December (i.e. 3 days after the task is assigned) and every 3 days from the 4th?

  • Yes

Scenario: Reminder email gets from 14th (i.e. 3 days before 17 Dec due date) and then every 3 days from the 14th?

  • No

Scenario: Reminder email gets triggered 17 December and every 3 days from the 17th? OR Reminder email gets triggered 1 day after the due date so from 18 Dec and every 3 days from 18th?

  • It will trigger 3 days after the due date and the number of times based on the configuration until the task is complete.

I am testing on my demo to confirm the "0" number of reminders. If it still behaves like an old test I did.

I will share the results here, once I have at least a day to "reminders be triggered".

Best regards,
Jacson
SAP Support

entry.title: A Day of Innovation, Insight & Intelligent Conversations: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025
entry.content:
A Day of Innovation, Insight & Intelligent Conversations: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025

SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025 was more than an event — it was a full day of learning, exchange of ideas, and meaningful community moments. Hosted with the support of AWS, Mindset, ROJO Integrations, and SAP Press, the gathering brought together professionals from across the SAP ecosystem: developers, consultants, architects, leaders, learners, and enthusiasts.

Right from the first interaction at the registration desk, there was a sense of purpose and curiosity in the air. Everyone walked in with a shared goal: to understand where the world of enterprise technology is heading next.

SAP GGN Community Core Team for SAP Insider Track GGN 2025 – Third Edition

 

A Warm and Powerful Beginning

The day began with organized registrations and structured networking, giving participants the opportunity to connect and align their expectations for the event. The event kicked off with a warm welcome from Aseem Khera, Location Head, ​SAP Labs India Gurugram​ clearly outlining the agenda and highlighting the day’s objectives. His opening remarks established a clear framework and set the tone for subsequent sessions.

Aseem Khera, Location Head, ​SAP Labs India Gurugram​ 

 

This was followed by an inspiring video keynote from Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM. In her address, she highlighted the importance of the SAP Community, the effects of artificial intelligence on the global economy, and SAP's AI-First, Suite-First strategy.

Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM

 

 

The morning session continued with an inspiring SAP Business AI strategy talk by Sudhir Verma, Head of Technology & Architecture ​Private Cloud Products titled “Transforming Business with SAP Business AI.” He provided a comprehensive and insightful overview of the ongoing transformation of SAP Business AI strategy.

Sudhir Verma, Head of Technology & Architecture ​Private Cloud Products

 

A huge shout-out to our amazing host, Akansha Tiwari! Your energy, charm, and effortless hosting truly made the event unforgettable. Your poised and engaging presence kept the momentum alive throughout the entire morning session. The way you connected with the audience, guided transitions with ease, and maintained a vibrant atmosphere played a pivotal role in the event’s overall success.

 

Akansha Tiwari - Host of the Event

 

 

Three Tracks, Three Journeys, One Purpose

The event went beyond treating technology as a concept, organizing learning into three parallel tracks tailored to different participant needs. Each track offered practical, actionable insights—catering to leaders, developers, and hands-on learners alike—allowing attendees to explore strategies, tools, and real-world applications in a focused and meaningful way aligned with their roles and professional goals.

Agenda of the day with Session Title & Speaker Names

 

Track 01: SAP Business AI Strategy & Roadmap​ / SAP Business AI Products

Ideal for architects, leaders, and decision-makers

This track focused on understanding how organizations can evolve their systems, processes, and governance models. Speakers shared their experiences on:

  • Strengthening enterprise value
  • Navigating regulatory landscapes
  • Modernizing GRC
  • Evolving SuccessFactors experiences
  • Positioning SAP’s latest offerings for business outcomes

The conversations weren’t theoretical—they were grounded in real decisions and real impact.

 

Track 02: Embedded AI in SAP Solutions​ / Building with SAP AI Agents​

Built for developers, engineers, and product builders

This track showcased what happens when ideas take shape. From building custom solutions to exploring new toolkits, participants learned how to translate concepts into working applications.

Sessions covered:

  • Building custom agents
  • Optimizing catalogs
  • Ensuring safety in high-risk industries
  • Handling real-time situations in S/4HANA
  • Enhancing HR processes with modern tools

Every session was centered around solving real business challenges.

 

Track 03: Hands-On Workshops

For those who understand best by doing

This track remained one of the most crowded for a reason—it was all action.

Participants practiced:

  • Generate an SAP Fiori app from an image​
  • Generate an SAP Fiori app from business requirements​
  • Generate and enhance an app​
  • Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAP​

It was a genuine “roll-up-your-sleeves” experience.

 

Afternoon Deep Dives: Practical Stories & Lessons

Post lunch, the sessions transitioned to in-depth case studies and practical, real-world scenarios. Speakers provided valuable insights on topics such as:

  • Detecting fraud within business systems
  • Optimizing development cycles
  • Managing responsible digital processes
  • Enhancing commercial operations
  • Improving employee experiences in live environments

These discussions effectively bridged technology with day-to-day organizational decisions, demonstrating tangible applications and measurable outcomes for participants.

 

The Heart of the Day: Conversations & Community

SAP Inside Track events have always been known for their community-driven spirit. Gurugram 2025 continued that legacy beautifully.

Corridors, break areas, and even the workshop tables stayed alive with:

  • Debates on implementation challenges
  • Exchange of tips and best practices
  • Discussions on new roles and skills
  • Shared excitement for the future of enterprise systems

For many, these conversations were just as valuable as the sessions themselves.

 

A Fitting Closure

The day wrapped up with a closing ceremony followed by snacks and informal networking. People walked out with new connections, refreshed perspectives, and a deeper appreciation for how powerful the SAP community is when it comes together.

entry.title: Re: Lumpsum issue - guidelines show 0 and Lumpsum field cannot be filled in the form
entry.content: I would need to see your guidelines to see why they are blank. You have to ensure your guideline parameters are met for each employee and the lump sum guideline field is visible. Also, make sure you have a default value at the bottom with * for each parameter so ensure if an employee falls through, those guidelines will appear. Remember, the guidelines are read in numerical order, meaning row 1 then row 2 etc. If they hit a match with row 1, the system will never hit row 2.

entry.title: Re: Alternate Reconciliation Account and Overwriting control accounts initiated by MM through ERS
entry.content: Hi @KoijMikami, Currently, there is no standard way to use alternate reconciliation accounts with ERS in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. The MRM_ERS_DATA_Modify_CE BAdI does not include reconciliation account parameters, and forcing overwrite through Open FI is not feasible due to the automated nature of ERS processing. Consider process alternatives or submit enhancement requests for future product development.

entry.title: Main resource and additional resource cost journal ( 6***) not generated after Production Operation
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are implementing SAP Business ByDesign for a customer in the garment manufacturing industry and have scoped both Manufacturing and Product Costing functionalities.

Issue:
Our Bill of Operations consists of three operations, and each operation has a main resource (Labour) and an additional resource (Indirect Costs) assigned. However, upon completing the production operation, the system only posts the raw material consumption journal (Raw Material Inventory CR / Work in Process DR).
The system does not post any resource cost journals (6*** internal services CR / Work in Process DR).

Expectation:
For each completed operation, we expect ByDesign to post resource cost journals to WIP, so that month-end WIP correctly reflects both material costs and resource (labour and indirect) costs at the operation level.
In addition, for Actual Costing to work correctly, resource costs must be posted during the production confirmation process.

Request for Clarification:

  1. Is it standard functionality in ByDesign that resource costs (both main and additional resources) are posted to WIP when the production task associated with an operation is completed?

  2. What could be the possible reasons or configuration gaps that would prevent the system from posting resource cost journals?

Thank you,
Sagar

entry.title: Re: Error M8_2210 during MIRO. Item is not consistent
entry.content: consider the following steps: 1. Check Service Entry Sheet: Ensure that the Service Entry Sheet related to the purchase order is correctly created and approved. Any discrepancies in the Service Entry Sheet can lead to inconsistencies during MIRO processing. 2. Review Purchase Order Details: Verify that all details in the purchase order, especially those related to asset categories, are correctly maintained. Inconsistencies in asset categorization can trigger this error. 3. Account Assignment: Ensure that the account assignment in the purchase order is complete and correct. Missing or incorrect account assignments can cause the system to flag the item as inconsistent. 4. Configuration Check: Review the configuration settings for invoice verification in the system. Ensure that all necessary settings for handling asset-related purchase orders are correctly configured. 5. System Trace and Logs: Run a system trace or check logs to identify any specific inconsistencies or errors that might not be immediately visible. This can help pinpoint the exact cause of the inconsistency. If these steps do not resolve the issue, consider reaching out to SAP support for further assistance, providing them with detailed logs and screenshots to facilitate troubleshooting.

entry.title: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Errors during the Mass Creation of Business Partner Relationships
entry.content:
Hello Experts,
we have the following issue during the migration of 2000 Business Partner relationships.
We are using the app  "Manage Mass Creation Processes - BP Relationships (F6560A)" to import BP-Relationships for existing Business Partners.
We split the import into batches of 500, but if we try to activate these, then the system activates 100 of those and then gives the following error:
"User SAP_WFRT is processing the business partners relationship XY"
The error counter varies, if you reprocess the activation, sometimes it goes up one or two, then it drops down, till it activates another 100 entries. Eventually it activates all 500, so we were able to import the first batch. All of this takes a lot of time.

Our question is, is this standard behavior ? Can the tool only import 100 relationships at once and then needs time to process some stuff in the background ? 

We appreciate and advice on how to improve this process.
Best regards
Lukas

entry.title: Prompt-Driven Development: Building Full-Stack SAP CAP Apps from User Stories
entry.content:
Introduction

  • What if you could translate a business requirement into a functional, full-stack application with a single prompt?
  • How much faster could you deliver value if the foundational code and project scaffolding were generated for you in seconds?

This is the new reality powered by SAP Build Code and its integrated AI copilot, Joule.

As a turn-key environment on the SAP Business Technology Platform, it unifies the entire development lifecycle, from coding to deployment.

This post demonstrates how to build a full-stack SAP CAP application directly from a user story, showcasing how

generative AI is fundamentally reshaping the developer experience.

 

Business Requirement

Build an SAP CAP application based on the requirements in the user story below:

User Story

As a contract administrator, I want to create and manage contracts and ‘parties involved’ information in the system,

so that I can effectively track and handle legal agreements and ‘parties involved’ interactions.

Contracts can cover a vast range of agreements, such as sales contracts, service agreements and employment contracts.

Party involved: A ‘party involved’ is an individual, organization, or entity that purchases goods, products, or services from another party,

typically a business or seller.

Common attributes of a contract might include:

  1. Contract ID: A unique identifier for the contract.
  2. Party involved Identification Number: A unique identification number for the party involved.
  3. Contract Type: The type of contract (e.g. sales, service, employment).
  4. Start Date: The date on which the contract becomes valid.
  5. End Date: The date on which the contract expires (if applicable).
  6. Status: The current status of the contract (draft, active, expired, terminated, etc.)

A typical ‘party involved’ has the following attributes:

  1. Party involved Identification Number
  2. Party involved Name: It refers to the given name of a person or entity, or a label by which they are addressed or identified.
  3. Party involved Address: It refers to a physical location where an individual, business, or entity is situated or can be reached.
  4. Party involved Contact Information

Acceptance Criteria

Scenario 1: List All Contracts

Given I am logged into the contract management system, when I launch the SAP Fiori application to maintain contracts,

then I should be able to view the list of all the contracts in a list without pressing the GO button.

The list of all the contracts should have : Contract ID, Party involved Identification Number, Contract Type and Start Date. 

The list of filters should include Contract Type, Contract Status and Start Date.

Scenario 2: View Contract Details 

Given I am logged into the contract management system, when I select a specific contract from the list of SAP Fiori application,

then I should be able to view the contract details and parties involved information.

 

Joule's Generative AI-based SAP CAP App Development

Prerequisites

  • Get a Free Account on SAP BTP Trial
  • Setup SAP Build Code

1. Create a New Project using SAP Build Lobby

Create a Project

 

Click the Application Tile

Full-Stack

Full-Stack Node.JS

Contract Management

Contract Management

Project Created

2. Build a Full-Stack CAP Application via Prompt

Click the created project to open it in SAP Business Application Studio

Open Joule From the Activity Bar and  select the ’/cap-gen-app` slash command

Generate a CAP Application

Prompt the user story description(refer to Business Requirement section above) to Joule and click send.

Joule tackles complex tasks by breaking them into steps, each with a suggested prompt.

Diffrerent Steps

To simplify the process and provide full context, replace the content of each step with the complete user story prompt.

Then, save and run to generate each step's artifacts.

Accept the Code.

Accept the Code

Generated Artifacts

3. Add UI to the Application

Create a new Fiori elements Application.

Fiori Elements Application

 

3. Preview the Application

Click run to preview the Application.

Run the Application

The application’s preview is displayed.

Application Preview

Launch the contract management app.

Contract Management

Select a contract from the list to view its details.

Select Contract

 

Contract details

Conclusion

The journey from user story to a functional, full-stack application—once a multi-day endeavor—is now accomplished in minutes.

With SAP Build Code and its AI copilot, Joule, this dramatic acceleration signals a fundamental paradigm shift.

The developer's role is being elevated from the meticulous craft of writing code to the strategic art of guiding its creation.

Joule operates as the quintessential collaborator, executing the foundational groundwork to liberate developers to focus

on high-value business logic and innovation.

SAP Build Code is therefore more than a tool; it's the dawn of an era where the speed of technology finally

matches the ambition of business.

 

Further Information

SAP Build Code

#SAPBuildCode #Joule #SAPBTP

 

______________________________________________________________________________________________

 

 

Best Regards,
Anuradha Dhingan

entry.title: Re: Why does SAP always use Periodic Unit Price for valua...
entry.content:
Dear @esterwang,

Question 1.

  • In SAP, price control has exactly two options:
    • S Standard price
    • V Moving average price / periodic unit price

More details from SAP Press blog:

https://blog.sap-press.com/accounting-views-in-the-material-master

  • With V, SAP explicitly defines that the valuation of stock is based on the moving average / periodic unit price, not the standard price. In SAP help under Valuation with Moving Average Price, SAP states that with moving average price control, a new material price is calculated after every goods movement or invoice receipt

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/5e23dc8fe9be4fd496f8ab556667ea05/bef1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/bbd9b6ce0be14516ad7868da0982024a.html

  • Because Material Ledger is mandatory in S/4HANA for material valuation, the moving price for price control V is technically the Periodic Unit Price (PUP) in the ML tables. The official Material valuation in S/4HANA content explicitly points out that Material Ledger is required and refers to simplification item/SAP Note 2267835 about statistical moving average price

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/2267835

So when you choose price control V, you are telling the system: Value this material based on the moving average / periodic unit price (PUP), not based on a fixed standard price. That’s why you always see PUP as the valuation basis.

Concrete technical evidence:

  1. Field semantics in MBEW
    The table documentation for MBEW shows:
    • Price control values: S = Standard price, V = Moving average price/periodic unit price
      The valuation is then done with:
    • STPRS Standard price only used when price control = S
    • VERPR Moving average price / PUP used when price control = V
  2. Material Ledger / Accounting 1 view
    The classic Actual Costing documentation explains that in Accounting 1, the periodic unit price for the previous period is displayed as the moving price when price control = V
  3. In the SAP PRESS book Material Ledger in SAP S/4HANA, the reading sample shows a material with price control V and two price fields Standard Price and Per unit price. The note explicitly states that because price control is V, Per unit price is the valuation price and Standard price is not

Summary: You observe that valuation always using the periodic unit price is exactly what SAP designed

Question 2.

  • SAP defines in configuration Define Price Control for Material Types (OMW1) that you can choose V moving average price/periodic unit price or S standard price as the valuation method for a material type. But this customizing just sets defaults it does not change how valuation is calculated
  • The help for Price Control and Material Price Determination clarifies that:
    • Price control = V valuation is at moving average/periodic unit price
    • Price control = S valuation is at standard price

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/5e23dc8fe9be4fd496f8ab556667ea05/5af1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

  • The system logic that decides which field (STPRS vs. VERPR) is used in FI postings is not configurable it is standard program logic based on price control

What configuration does influence

  • Material price determination (2 vs 3) tells ML how to calculate PUP and variances, not which field to use for valuation.
    • With Price Determination 2 (transaction-based) and price control V the material is valued at moving average price with price control S, at standard price
    • With Price Determination 3 (single-/multilevel) and price control S, Actual Costing determines a PUP and can revalue inventory but the preliminary valuation during the period is at standard price

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/5e23dc8fe9be4fd496f8ab556667ea05/6cf1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/6cf1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

Question 3.

In S/4HANA, when price control = V, the Standard Price field is basically statistical / reference only, it’s not used for stock valuation.

Practically, under V, standard price is used for:

  1. Planning and costing
    • As a reference price in cost estimates (CK11N/CK40N) or CO planning.
    • For comparisons between target (standard) and actual (PUP/MAP).
  2. Information and reporting
    • To store a management/planned cost for the material, independent of the moving/PUP valuation.
  3. Conversion scenarios
    • During conversions or switching between S and V, SAP sometimes copies one price into the other to avoid valuation jumps, but once a period is running with V, STPRS is no longer the controlling price

Summary: From a pure valuation perspective, standard price has no posting effect when price control is V.

Question 4.

Below SAP Help documentation for version On-Premise and Cloud:

  1. Price Control and moving average price
    • Valuation with Moving Average Price clearly states that with moving average price control, a new material price is calculated after every goods movement / invoice / settlement

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/bbd9b6ce0be14516ad7868da0982024a.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/5e23dc8fe9be4fd496f8ab556667ea05/bef1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

    • Negative Stocks at Moving Average Price – explicitly refers to Price control V Moving average price/periodic unit price in Accounting 1

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ERP/96bf9ad642cf4b26a29595e3d573fb8c/3657b953cccbb34ce10000000a174cb4.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/04c8a518f5934c1faf690f30f4b74722.html

  1. Basic concepts of price control and ML
    • Basic Concepts of Price Control describes Moving average price (Periodic Unit Price) and ML indicator shows that for MAP/PUP valuation, price control V is used

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/erpscm/3362168424.html

  1. Price Control and Material Price Determination
    • Help topic Price Control and Material Price Determination explains how price control and price determination interact and that Actual Costing for PUP requires price control S with price determination 3, reinforcing that V is the MAP/PUP path, S is standard-price path

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/af9ef57f504840d2b81be8667206d485/5af1d353ca9f4408e10000000a174cb4.html

  1. Transaction-based price determination
    • Articles on Material Price Determination in SAP Material Ledger and Materials 2V price determination 2 price control V show the standard combination 2V and that these materials are valued at moving average price

More details below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/material-price-determination-in-sap-material-ledger-sap-s-4hana-public/ba-p/13556561

SAP Notes below:

  • 2267834 S4TWL Material Ledger Obligatory for Material Valuation
    Confirms that Material Ledger is mandatory in S/4HANA hence PUP is central to valuation
  • 2267835 S4TWL Material Valuation Statistical moving average price
    Explains how the former statistical moving average price concept changes in S/4HANA and how the MAP/PUP field MBEW-VERPR behaves

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/ficontrolling/3361878146.html

These notes don’t change the basic rule, but they show SAP official stance on price fields and ML in S/4HANA

SAP Press

  1. Blog: Accounting Views in the Material Master adapted from Introducing the Material Master in SAP S/4HANA
    • Describes price control S vs V price control V is explicitly Moving Average Price/Periodic Unit Price, a variable price calculated based on goods movements and invoice postings

More details below:

https://blog.sap-press.com/accounting-views-in-the-material-master

  1. Blog: What Is the Difference Between Moving Average Price and Standard Price in SAP?
    • Illustrates that when price control field contains value V, the system uses the moving average price method: inventory is posted at the average price after each receipt when it’s S, the system always uses the fixed standard price and posts variances separately

More details below:

https://blog.sap-press.com/what-is-the-difference-between-moving-average-price-and-standard-price-in-sap

These are good external but still very official-feeling references

Question 5.

From SAP design perspective you are meant to choose one of two costing philosophies per material:

  1. Standard Costing (price control = S)
    • Valuation at a fixed standard price for the period.
    • All differences go to price difference accounts.
    • Actual Costing (PUP) with ML is an additional periodic view you can choose to revalue or not.
  2. Moving / Actual Costing (price control = V)
    • Valuation always follows the current average/periodic unit price derived from actual receipts and adjustments.
    • No separate “standard price” basis for valuation.

Letting standard price drive valuation while price control = V would:

  • Contradict the meaning of price control in MM and FI
  • Break a lot of ML and reconciliation logic
  • Make postings and cost flows ambiguous which price is real for stock vs. variances

That’s why SAP keeps a clear split:

  • If you want valuation at standard price, use price control S ideally with price determination 3 for Actual Costing
  • If you want valuation at actual average/periodic cost use price control V

Summary: For price control = V in S/4HANA, the valuation price is always the moving average / periodic unit price field (MBEW-VERPR). The Standard Price field (MBEW-STPRS) is then only informational. This is standard SAP design and not something you can switch by configuration

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Lease in Accounting - migration / special flow
entry.content:
Hello @marcel_f 

Thank you for your question.

First, let me address the reason why you see the “special flow”. In Lease Accounting the system always reconciles lease liability and right of use (ROU) asset. If, at your chosen valuation date, those two balances are not equal, the system will place the valuation cash flow as a special flow. It will then post it to the account you assigned in your valuation rule. This could easily happen during migration especially when you:

  • Fix an interest rate and the valuation date in your new contract, but
  • You forget to model all past changes (e.g., rent charges or index changes) that happened in your legacy system.

That means your system therefore calculates a present value of 341,195,38 EUR while the migrated ROU asset is 329,544,76 EUR . Then the system books the gap of 11,650,62 EUR as negative equity change (special flow IB00) in other to ensure ROU and liability balances are aligned. You can find more details on that here: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3055448

Second, the response you received on why you cannot fix both NPV and interest rate is correct. You cannot have both a manually fixed NPV and fixed rate at the same time. If you try to force both, you will break the internal logic and your subsequent calculation will not longer match IFRS 16 formulas. This is exactly what you experienced.

Finally, the public cloud does not offer any customising, SSCUI or BAdI that can suppress IB00. You can only functionally avoid it by modelling your historic lease condition so that the present value equals the ROU amount. Otherwise, I recommend you:

  • Treat IB00 as the technical adjustment that aligns your migrated ROU and liability.
  • Make sure your special flow accounts in your valuation rule are set to appropriate equity and ROU adjustment accounts.
  • Also, ensure you document in your accounting manual that this item represents the difference between the legacy balances and the balance implied by the new valuation.

For more guidance on Leasing configuration, see the link below:

https://help.sap.com/doc/76d00f8803a845a28297e5ca3087cfd4/7.0.2/en-US/SAP%20Leasing%20-%20Configuration%20Guide%202011.pdf

entry.title: How to Modify Standard SLED using a BAdI- VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT
entry.content:
Synopsis- There should some functionality either to influence( change) the Shelf Life Expiry Date( SLED) or Remaining shelf life in some exceptional cases, primarily in Consumer based industry.

Requirement- Recently working with Food Processing company, we were tasked to reduce SLED by some N days after standard calculation. The business involves Finished goods produced as 'Fresh' but its latter converted into new Product Called as 'Fresh as Frozen'. In this process of product conversion, Mat 2 Mat transfer(Fresh to Fresh as Frozen), a new SLED is also calculated for target material on the day of posting. Primarily, SLED of new product has to be reduced by 2 Days.

Solution- Since the core of the solution was built on custom RF( Using /SCWM/POST and some Idea from MIGO( WM Packing) New screen), we called a BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT. Basically the BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT is meant to change the process parameters in the shelf life expiration handling. The SLED of a material is changed during the goods movement posting process( Mvt Type) called inside the BAdI.

Badi has the method MAINTAIN_SLED_PARAMETERS allows to change all the relevant parameters of shelf life expiration date processing for goods movements.

Requirement- Recently working with Food Processing company, we were tasked to reduce SLED by some N days after standard calculation. The business involves Finished goods produced as 'Fresh' but its latter converted into new Product Called as 'Fresh as Frozen'. In this process of product conversion, Mat 2 Mat transfer(Fresh to Fresh as Frozen), a new SLED is also calculated for target material on the day of posting. Primarily, SLED of new product has to be reduced by 2 Days.

Solution- Since the core of the solution was built on custom RF( Using /SCWM/POST and some Idea from MIGO( WM Packing) New screen), we called a BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT. Basically the BAdI VB_SLED_MANAGEMENT is meant to change the process parameters in the shelf life expiration handling. The SLED of a material is changed during the goods movement posting process( Mvt Type) called inside the BAdI.

Badi has the method MAINTAIN_SLED_PARAMETERS allows to change all the relevant parameters of shelf life expiration date processing for goods movements.

Using this, the SLED parameters of the material master can be changed.

  • Total shelf life (C_MHDHB)

  • Remaining shelf life (C_MHDRZ)

  • Period indicator (C_IPRKZ_HBD/C_IPRKZ_RLZ)

  • Rounding rule (C_RDMHD)

The two additional parameters C_HSDAT and C_VFDAT allow changes to the contents of dialog fields Date of manufacture (DM07M-HSDAT_INPUT) and Shelf life expiration date (DM07M-VFDAT_INPUT).In below example, BAdI was called in custom RF( Which also had Batch Creation Bapi along with Mat 2 Mat conversion logic with HU creation)

Once Material 2 Material transfer is triggered, batch was created with reduced SLED( Minus 2 days from Standard calculation)

Date of Production= 04.12.2025

Total Shelf Life=16 days

Stnd SLED= 04.12.2025+ 16= 20.12.2025

Revised SLED by BAdI= 20.12.2025- 2= 18.12.2025( The offset days is maintained TVARV at Material group level)

All changes are recorded in Batch master.

CALC and CCHECK can be changed as required in method MAINTAIN_SLED_PARAMETERS (for example 'Check only' => C_CALC = SPACE, C_CHECK = 'X'). We used Plant +Mvt Type to stop the recalculation of SLED by passing C_CALC=SPACE as other plants should not be impacted with this change.

Please read all the documentation of BAdI mentioned in documentation carefully before implementing it.

entry.title: SAP Integration with SAP Concur Solutions: What's New in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In SAP ICS we have often new information for you on the basis of What's New links.  For example, since we aim to send out the SAP ICS newsletter before the Release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we always refer to the Preliminary What's New. 

The Preliminary What’s New is available only for a short period ahead of a release. The What’s New then becomes available on the release date. 

On the release date, you can easily find What’s New topics for SAP ICS using the What’s New Viewer by applying just a few filters:

  • Line of Business = Finance
  • Solution Area = Travel Management
  • Scope Item = 1M1
  • Valid as Of = [Release version you want to view].

Check out the What's New for the 2508 S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Release as an example. 

General information can also be found here: How to Use the What’s New Viewer.

entry.title: The Future of Procurement and Maintenance: Bridging the Gap for Lasting Impact
entry.content:
The Future of Procurement and Maintenance: Bridging the Gap for Lasting Impact 🚀

In today’s rapidly evolving business landscape, the intersection of procurement and maintenance is more critical than ever. The recent conversation with Aaron Horne, SAP Solution Advisor and a newly appointed member of the SAP Center of Excellence, sheds light on the challenges, opportunities, and emerging trends shaping the future of procurement, especially in maintenance, repair, and operations (MRO). This post distills the most salient insights from the discussion, offering actionable takeaways for professionals navigating this dynamic space.

From Engineering to Procurement: A Unique Perspective 🔄

Aaron’s journey from mechanical engineering and oil refinery project management to procurement advisory highlights the value of cross-functional expertise. His transition was driven by firsthand experience with the migration from Oracle to SAP, where he saw the importance of connecting maintenance data and processes with procurement systems. This blend of technical and operational knowledge enables a deeper understanding of the real-world needs of maintenance teams—a perspective often overlooked in traditional procurement strategies.

The Maintenance–Procurement Divide: Breaking Down Barriers 🛠️🤝

A recurring theme in the discussion is the historical friction between maintenance professionals and procurement teams. Maintenance managers, focused on keeping plants running, often perceive procurement as a barrier—more concerned with cost savings and compliance than operational continuity. Aaron candidly admits to having “hated” procurement processes in his previous roles, not because of the people, but due to conflicting priorities. The key insight here is the need for empathy and collaboration: procurement must understand the urgency and complexity of maintenance operations, while maintenance teams should appreciate the value procurement brings in supplier management and compliance.

Technology as an Enabler: AI, Automation, and User Experience 🤖✨

Emerging technologies, especially AI and automation, are transforming the procurement–maintenance relationship. The transcript highlights several forward-looking use cases:

  • Generative AI for Diagnostics and Inventory: Imagine a technician describing equipment symptoms and AI instantly identifying the right parts from inventory, streamlining repairs and reducing downtime. This not only improves efficiency but also enhances user experience for maintenance professionals.🧠
  • Predictive Analytics for Supply Chain: AI-driven forecasting can anticipate changes in maintenance schedules, ensuring suppliers are prepared for sudden spikes in demand. This proactive approach minimizes disruptions and supports better planning.📊
  • Document Intelligence: AI tools that can sift through hundreds of pages of manuals to extract relevant procedures or warranty information empower technicians to act quickly and accurately.📚

These innovations promise to make procurement tools more appealing and accessible to end users, fostering greater adoption and maturity in enterprise systems.

Collaboration and Continuous Improvement: The Path Forward 🤲🔄

The future of procurement and MRO lies in ongoing collaboration and feedback. Aaron emphasizes the importance of involving maintenance professionals in procurement decisions—from supplier selection to process design. Organizations that bring “boots on the ground” into the conversation are better positioned to align priorities and avoid costly missteps. Moreover, continuous improvement—adopting new features, refining processes, and maintaining open channels for product feedback—ensures that both procurement and maintenance can adapt to changing business needs.  

Conclusion: Building Bridges for Sustainable Success 🌉

The conversation with Aaron underscores a powerful message: the future of procurement is not just about better products or smarter technology, but about building bridges between teams, fostering empathy, and driving continuous improvement. By embracing collaboration, leveraging AI, and prioritizing user experience, organizations can unlock new levels of efficiency and resilience in their supply chains.

Ready to shape the future? Share your thoughts, feedback, or experiences in the comments below—let’s keep the conversation going! 💬 email: thefutureofprocurement@sap.com

🌐 OpenSAP: Entire Series HERE!

🍎 Apple Podcasts: Listen on Apple!

Spotify:  Listen on Spotify HERE!

Audible: Listen on Audible HERE!

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4: Final What's New & Product Assistance available
entry.content:
With immediate effect, the final What's New information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4 is now available.

To access the final What’s New information, please use the What’s New Viewer. In addition, the final Product Assistance (aka Application Help) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4 is available. Please use the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Help Portal page to access it.

For you as a customer, we recommend to also use the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool. The Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool provides you with a personalized and tailored view on What’s New information based on the activated and used scope within your system. The information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4 will be available in RASD within the next few days. A valid Customer S-user ID is required for login. We recommend to use RASD to prepare for upgrades and updates of your system and to focus on the new and changed features that are relevant for you as a customer.

You can use the commenting feature for What’s New. With this feature, authors can evaluate your feedback and incorporate it into the documentation, if needed. We hope that by opening this channel of communication, we can learn how to further improve our What’s New content for you. To use this feature, you need to be logged into the Help Portal. The feature will only be available in the English version of the documents. To learn more about how the feedback process works in SAP Help Portal, see Giving Documentation Feedback.

entry.title: S4 Public Cloud如何实现使用文档凭证功能，同时将制造图纸等文件保留在本地
entry.content:
咨询大家有熟悉ECC DMS的顾问么？

中国客户的德国子公司在实施从ECC切换到S4 Public Cloud的项目。

德国子公司用户的现有制造图纸等文件 通过文档凭证存在ECC里，但原始文件还是在本地服务器上。 文档凭证是挂图纸文件的凭证，可以做文件版本管理（ECC DMS）。

如果从ECC切换到S4 Public Cloud，德国子公司用户希望文件不上传到S4 Public Cloud，只创建文档凭证，文件放在德国本地。S4 Public Cloud有对应的实现方案吗？

德国用户得知如果使用S4 Public Cloud，需要把文件传到S4 Public Cloud，担心安全问题，不愿意传，但又要使用文档凭证功能。希望和SAP熟悉DMS的专家有机会沟通。非常感谢。

entry.title: Re: Manage Service Orders & Maintenance Order within SSAM...
entry.content:
Hi,

 

Initially, SAP Service and Asset Manager (SSAM) is a unified solution that allows you to manage both asset management and maintenance services, regardless of the business process (IS-U or any other). Therefore, there is no need to implement two separate mobile applications. You can use a single mobile application to manage both maintenance orders related to asset management and those associated with IS-U.

However, you should note that the design and configuration of the application may vary slightly depending on the specific requirements of each scenario. SAP SSAM offers flexibility in terms of configurations and functionalities that you can enable or disable based on the type of process you are managing, allowing you to have a single application for both types of processes. It will only be necessary to segment or differentiate the screens, functionalities, or roles according to the process you are managing (Asset Management or IS-U).

SAP Field Service Management (FSM) is designed to be as flexible as possible and allows you to configure and manage different scenarios within a single company instance or configuration. You do not need to create separate companies to manage different processes.

Instead of creating separate companies, FSM allows you to manage different operational units or entities within a single company configuration through service organizations and operational entities. This functionality will enable you to manage various maintenance and service processes within the same organizational structure without complicating the configuration with multiple instances.

However, if you have very specific needs or a high degree of complexity in the operation that justifies separating the configurations, you always have the option to implement additional configurations. But in most cases, managing everything from a single configuration is more efficient and cost-effective.

We have a similar solution, but what really helped us integrate everything was SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI). We had to develop an integration between SAP S/4HANA, SAP Field Service Management, and SAP Service Cloud, and it was through CPI that we were able to do so. Thanks to this integration, we only had to use the SAP FSM mobile app, without the need to implement any other additional applications.
